How is that slam and Trump being the authoritarian holding up over history?  Seems like Biden is just as bad, and while this was all started under Bush, Obama did nothing but continue it.  Important point is also that Biden, as a member of congress, was literally at the front of the line in supporting legislation that eroded our rights and increased the surveillance state.  I am no fan of orange man, but ya know, it is misleading to the point of a bias confirmation for those on the blue side thay their politicians aren't part of the same system, despite mountains of evidence that they are.  As an information channel, I encourage you to do better than that.  As an independent, mostly Libertarian, I can barely see the effective difference between the two parties.  They both want to erode our freedoms and increase state power.  I encourage you to create content that is actually politically neutral, because when you show a bias, you undermine being more inclusive to audiences that also need this message and weaken the argument, because if you demonstrate one bias, then what other biases are underlying your work?  Great video overall, just sharing my thoughts on how it could be improved.  Namaste

Even if there needs to be surveillance in order to stop terrorist attacks, the information gathered should in no way be admissible in run of the mill criminal cases. This just creates an incentive for the surveillance powers to be used inappropriately. The only exceptions should be to prosecute human traffickers, or stop imminent harm (which would be given more importance than the prosecution). And the scope should still be as limited as possible.

We could aggregate data to allocate resources to the police, saying that publicly available information suggests a rate of X crime in a particular locale. However, the predictors of criminal behavior, applied to a single person is insanely dangerous when you apply the test to everyone. Any false positive rate greater than the chance that a random person would commit the crime, would massively skew towards implicating innocent people (look at Bayes Theorem)

I'm not saying you're wrong, but isn't this just a "slippery slope" argument? Also, I'd say this is also a false dichotomy argument. Strict laws can be more secure if implemented correctly with proper safety measure to prevent abuse, there doesn't have to be an "either or" scenario exclusively. It's entirely within the realm of possibility to have strict laws that are non-invasive. People are just being narrow minded and not willing to go through the effort of fully exploring how to implement a strict rule with many safeguards attached to it as well. I'm not a law maker, but I find it hard to believe no one has once before thought to include wording that would protect certain civil liberties while acquiescing specific ones in the name of public security.

Such as with your example of Apple, there absolutely could be specific language included in a law granting backdoor access with very narrow terms on when it's applicable and carry heavy consequences for going around the process. This would effectively mean that law enforcement would be required to gain access on the record through official channels. That whole part you mentioned where they said they hacked the phones anyway is what this current thinking is getting us. This video isn't helping with what you think it is, it's just fostering a regressive mentality that refuses to look forward and figure out a safe way to get there.

The top 15-20 floors crushing the bottom 80-90 floors violates newtons 3rd law - if the force exerted on the lower, heavier structure (the towers were built bottom heavy i.e. more mass in lower sections for stability) was enough the destroy everything in its path, then it should have also destroyed itself in the process because every force has an equal and opposite reaction.
The laws of conservation of momentum suggest that with each impact, and each equal destruction of a static and moving object, the system would come to a rest when all the stored energy is dissipated.

“If you have nothing to hide, you have nothing to fear.”

There’s one big flaw with that argument: it fails to define the phrase “nothing to hide.” That’s a really open-ended, subjective, ambiguous phrase, one which puts all responsibility for security on individual people rather than the agencies who look into people (you know, the people who are actually in charge of security).

It’s a painfully simplistic way of addressing a very complicated issue.

What are the things a person may want to hide? Why would they want to hide them?

It assumes that there’s only a set list of things that are objectionable and, thus, what someone would ever want to hide. If you don’t have anything from that list in your record, you’re good.

But what if the people doing the inquiry decide something ELSE is objectionable? The rules can change depending on who is enforcing them, especially in this age of hyper-partisanship and extremist political beliefs. That makes “just don’t do anything wrong and you’ll be fine” a lot harder because what constitutes “anything wrong” is way more open-ended than its proponents want us to believe.

That’s why big governments with lots of positions and agencies and systems of oversight/checks and balances are better than small governments with fewer people (or dictatorships where only a select group is calling all the shots): these issues are complicated and require a lot of effort to unravel. Yeah, it creates a lot of red tape and can make the government slow to act/react, but it helps ensure that everything is given its due course.

Note I said “helps ensure,” not “guarantees.” No system of government is perfect. Big governments make plenty of mistakes. But to use those mistakes as an excuse to dismiss the system outright is obtuse at best, ignorant at worst.

While usually I like all of your videos, this one didn't do it for me. I don't think you guys did your research well enough on this matter, especially when you said "NSA has not stopped any major terrorist attacks." That's a very anecdotal and ironic statement as you really don't know how much truly goes on. Granted, I am an intelligence analyst so I have an unfair advantage, but I guess my point is that you're not "adding more hay." You're increasing how much hay you can look at. We don't "not focus on criminals," you just don't know if someone is a criminal until you find something incriminating. Surveillance has definitely prevented a sickening amount of death that I don't think you could quite understand with the research you did here. EO 12333, the patriot act, and various other bills passed by congress prevent you from being surveiied unless there's is a strong reason to. Indiscriminate surveillance is not how this video portrayed it either. No one is looking at your name on an email to your lover, but rather information on when you're bombing some building.  Very very inaccurate video, with a very confusing source list. Still love your channel.

“When looking for the needle in a haystack, adding more hay won’t help” - this is simply false and an oversimplification. As data mining and surveillance tools become better, we need to make sure that we are able to access and review more needles. A powerful metal detector searching a haystack is useless if the needle isn’t present.

These programs aren’t giving up our liberties and freedoms any more than having a police or military presence is. Police have the ability to harass and oppress because of the tools and authority they have. And regardless of whether or not they are oppressive, I don’t think anyone is talking about removing their presence altogether.

We need to become more educated about cyber security, rather than fearing it. We need smarter tools AND policies to protect our liberties.

I will present you with a question: Do you think by doing internet research and asking people that don't actually see the day to day work, you will ever know how much potential terrorist activity has been prevented? Obviously, if it has been prevented you would not know and see them on the news. I agree that agencies can be more transparent and report on what they've actually prevented but I would say most likely not going to happen because usually, it will give out the sources and methods when you answer the "how" factor when you make those things public. If you want something done right I guess you have to do it yourself. So how about we form a new political party? I believe, with the following ethos, we would have substantial support:
A government that does not monitor its citizens in any way unless there is reason to believe they are a threat to the safety of others.
One that respects, and encourages the growth of, its citizens' own intellect and common sense (removal of drug prohibition and removal of strict health and safety regulations for example)
A total reform of the entire education system, teaching our kids relevant information such as business, maths, science, networking, nutrition, sport, mindfulness, coding, and life skills.
Better education on how to make the right moral decisions without the need to look to religion, outdated texts that essentially harm our society by causing conflict and giving our children false ideas about the origin of the planet and the science that makes it work.
A far more proactive approach to the protection of the environment and conservation of wildlife.
Strict enforcement of 'green space' regulations, bringing nature back in to our cities for the benefit of not only the wildlife that would find home in these spaces but also the citizens that find home, or work, in the city.

...just to name a few, please feel free to add more...

I understand this would mean a complete reform of government, and a huge change in the way our country is led, but we cant just assume we've got it right. We can see from history that is not how anything in life works. Things evolve constantly. And I believe that as computers and social media have become such an integral part of society the time to rethink, redesign and reform is upon us.

I essentially take the opinion that, as things are, the government has far too much control over our lives, and ARE subtly moulding us into "ideal" citizens, robot like form. People are not encouraged to think for themselves and when this happens, we become malleable. And the tool we are then being shaped with is the media, and never have the government had more control over the media than now, the era of social media. I for one believe that this is not ok. And the only way to make a change is to be the change.

Good video on the whole. My comment would be that although I think you have the problem identified, and you've started thinking about better ways of dealing with it than what we're currently doing, I don't think you've necessarily thought the issue through fully. Freedom is good, but give freedom to a terrorist, and they may commit a nasty crime. I'm NOT advocating enhanced spying or ethnic profiling or anything. Those things are wrong. I'm just saying that the solution is to nurture a society that wants to be decent upstanding citizens. Most modern societies fail at that pretty badly these days, and the prime reason is not that humans are innately bad. We are innately good, but can have bad tendencies if we're put in situations that tempt us to be bad. If we encourage our societies to be moral (by basing what we do on good principles such as honesty and decency and hard work and fair distribution of resources, and transparency and encouraging a love for the environment and a strong sense of duty towards stewardship of it, and fairness and justice for all, including people in vulnerable circumstances like widows and orphans and ex-criminals...) then the problems will slowly disappear. This is a cultural thing. And it's a hard ask to get from where we are, to that sort of society, because one of the biggest evils inducing us to be bad is considered to be normal and good these days - namely money and the pursuit of money. We need to radically alter this system so it's impossible for some people to have such vast inequality of resources - which comes from the current set-up with the money system. That is hard, and will encounter a lot of opposition, but is nevertheless an indispensable tool in fighting the evils in our world. The system outlined by Christian Felber in his book Change Everything https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_for_the_Common_Good would be a good start I think.
But getting back to the principals and the problem I was getting at that I saw in this viedo: although freedom is great, and necessary, the greater the freedom, the greater the responsibility you have to use it wisely. Freedom is powerful, and with power should come responsibility. If people have shown that they're not moral, then they still deserve a little freedom, but less than people who are more moral. Unfortunately judging morality is extremely fraught with difficulties. It's possible that a lot of people in prison are quite moral people, but have been in difficult situations and had difficult upbringings and have just made a few bad decisions. And it's possible that a lot of people not in prison, people who are free and walking about on our streets and in our supermarkets and skyscrapers are actually quite immoral, but are just quietly biding their time and doing as many immoral actions as they can to get their way within the system (I know some people who seem like this.)
So, the goal is to have a society where people WANT to be good. To have that, we have to have a starting condition that nurtures and encourages this and makes it attainable. And it reduces the power and freedom and privileges (not removes, reduces,) those things for the people with low amounts of morality so they can see the benefits of it, and will work hard on becoming moral. The way to do this is to a) remove the power of the most evil things on the planet, the primary one of which, in my opinion right now is money, using a system such as the Economy for the Common Good, and b) encourage a culture of morality (which here in NZ and in many Western societies is being weakened, mostly by money and evil people who buy into money-is-good, such as right-wing organisations and parties,) with legislation that uses both stick and carrot to move us in that direction.

Some very deceptive mischaracterizations going on here. For instance, they say the FBI "lied" when the FBI said it needed help to break into the phone. The FBI did in fact need help. Factual errors like that and jumping right to "See, the FBI lied; they can't be trusted!!!!" undermine not just this video but the whole series of videos you guys produce. While I agree that many anti-terrorism laws have been abused, many have not and allow for much more effective surveillance of targets and their associates.

 Ultimately, the threat of terrorism on society is vast exaggerated and is more a matter of entertainment and 24/7 news obsession than real substance. Still, a big thumbs down for this bias and factually inconsistent video which came off more as political op-ad than education.

Dear Kurgesagt.
I utterly love and admire your incredible work. I want to express and opinion and small concern which is, I believe, you have reached and just surpassed the optimal amount of complexity and detail in your beautiful animations. I remember how I loved how minimalistic your first videos were. Adding shades and objects and motion is not helpful rather distracting after a certain point.
I know it's tempting to make beautifully rich material but while conveying such important and often hard to digest topics I would keep the level of detail closer to that of your first videos.
If you feel too close to the project and want to see a similar example check RSA animates (which you may have). Watch one of the first RSA animates and one of the last ones. The amazing Andrew Park started with simple, into the point sketches that were guiding our attention to the concepts but ended up with masterpieces of drawing that overflow the brain in the last vids.
You can also ask a teenager or just any person if your last vids are as easy to watch as the first ones.
Once again, you have earned my humble and sincere gratitude for the jaw-dropping work you are putting out, just wanted to express my opinion.

Regards & DFTBA

What terrorist threat? There's been like.. 2 total on US soil.
Its one of those things that has become a big deal just because we've uniformly decided that it is, but it really isn't a problem.

We've prioritized terrorism simply because the explosions are flashier. The real issues killing far more people aren't terrifying looking events with explosions so we've placed it lower on our list of priorities than terrorism - which is basically one or two isolated incidents with explosions.

Terrorism at this point is basically "bad shit sometimes happens". Thinking that you're going to catch every "bad guy" every time is just delusional. Terrorist attacks will happen, but fortunately they are incredibly rare. All this effort to tighten security is an emotional reaction, not a logical one.

Privacy also doesn't matter as long as the government can be trusted. The root of the privacy debate isn't whether or not privacy is important (because its not), but rather that the government can't be trusted to behave in a civil manner when given personal information that conflicts with their laws and ideals.

This video taps into a popular, poorly thought through narcissistic paranoia about the apparently omnipotent security services. There are over two million e-mails sent every minute in the UK alone. Think for a minute about the kind of resources it would take to read everyone's e-mails, text messages, facebook posts, you tube comments etc. Never mind the kind of resources it would take to track everyone's movements on CCTV...Unless you are planning to blow something up you are simply not that interesting. And if you are planning to blow something up then sorry, but I do want the security services all up in your business reading your e-mails. That's them doing their job.

What we need is proper oversight to ensure that legal powers are being used appropriately - of course laws criminalising the criticism of government are wrong but we can't simultaneously demonise the security services for doing their job and then shake angry fists at them and shout "you should have seen this coming!" when an act of terrorism actually does happen.

Reasonable balance is the key. Security without liberty is tyranny. Liberty without security is fantasy.

Sorry Kurzesagt, but for the first time I have to disagree with your video.  I am a paranoid schizophrenic and have spent many years in fear of some entity being able to survey me even if I was in the middle of the woods.  In the end I have made peace with a few things.  First of all I am fine with everything being known about me, no one is perfect and we all stray from the best thing at hand.  However I believe that short of violent crimes, we should have nothing to fear.  And I blindly put faith in the fact that the powers that be are capable of using restraint to brush off anything that doesn't harm another.  The one and only reason I fear big brother is in a futuristic "Minority report" situation.  If we have faith in the powers that be to use discretion and continue to do so for the years that come, then we should in no way fear big brother.

There's a reason why many moderates, not just the right, are against gun control in the US and other countries. Ever since the Paris attacks, people in Europe have been trying to arm themselves because they feel that their government can't properly protect them, either arriving too late, or arriving outgunned (or non-gunned) and becoming victims themselves. In the US in recent years, people on the left have called for more gun control in the wake of mass shootings, but their solutions wouldn't have prevented what occurred, as was the case with Sandy Hook. The San Bernardino shooters broke nearly every firearm law in California leading up to and during the attack; laws that punish people after an attack don't do anything to prevent such actions, and are especially useless if they're not alive to punish.

Many of the proposals I hear from the left are long term solutions that seem to be aimed more at slowing or stopping general sales of firearms rather than short or immediate solutions like allowing civilians to carry for their own defense in more sensitive places. It's not something unfamiliar. Texas made it easier to carry weapons in restaurants after a mass shooter rampaged through a restaurant in 1991, and the only person legally allowed to defend themselves had to lock their gun in the car, and couldn't save anyone, including her parents.

While I personally agree with the things stated in this video, I really come to this channel and support it on Patreon more for informative, neutral videos, whether they be about science or social issues. The "we should do this" kind of statements in previous videos have always bothered me, but they were usually fairly minor, and generally backed up by the actual information in the video, so it somewhat made sense.

But this video just felt like a propaganda piece, or just an op-ed. There was very little factual information, most of it just seemed to be reiterating the point of government surveillance being bad (which, again, I do agree with). I think it would have been better to provide more neutral information, maybe explain how these surveillance programs work or what a golden key is, then give us some data about their actual results; and then maybe you could spend a few sentences on "hey guys, we should really stop this cuz it's dumb". But most of the actual facts and explanation seemed to have been glossed over for pure preaching...

Saying that more information makes it "harder to find the needles in the haystack" is a false analogy. Thanks to Big Data and the idea of Moore's Law, it doesn't matter how big the haystack is, because the speed at which that haystack is searched becomes ever faster regardless. One could argue that the "surveillance state" is inevitable on the grounds that every action in every location on the planet will soon be able to be captured in real time, with computers capable of telling us anything they see before we ask them what we're looking for.

Second point: you're jumping to some rather hasty conclusions in saying that the government "lied" in order to justify a backdoor. Tim Cook was vehement when he said that "our data encryption is so secure, not even we can crack it." They were 110% positive the FBI would never, EVER be able to get into that phone. And were that true, then the FBI would never have been able to brute force the phone. As soon as they did find a way, Apple immediately pressured the FBI to reveal how, so they could patch it and regain that "110% hackproof" status. Someone's being despicable in that scenario and it's no longer the FBI.

The problem is we fetishize the black box that is technology. We expect it to perform exactly as intended without having to think of how it works or how it's used. The very definition of a brute force attack is one of simplicity. Yet we've proven time and time again that PIN protection is a false layer of security (see http://lifehacker.com/5944567/the-most-and-least-common-pin-numbers-and-numeric-passwords-is-yours-one-of-them). When it gets down to it, if you put anything in yourself, on yourself, or on something that is connected to you, there is ALWAYS a chance that someone could take note of its existence. Even if it's embarrassing or unintentionally incriminating, you have to be able to take responsibility for the things that are a part of you.

The real issue is not the surveillance state, it's the idea that everyone is potentially a threat. In many respects, everyone on this planet is and is not a threat simultaneously. We all have the potential to wrong others, to hate others, but at the same time we all have restraint. The true injustice of your first example isn't that "all Muslims were put into a system," it's that "all Muslims were perceived as threats to national security." That's a far more encompassing issue because even if the Muslim community isn't /charged/ with anything, they are the ones who suffer as victims of prejudices inherent to the system.

I do believe there is a major hypocrisy here, when we ask the government and corporations to be transparent, yet guard ourselves and judge others around us who do the same.

The FBI didn't ask apple for assistance because they were being duplicitous and wanted a 'master key'. They asked because they weren't sure they could do it themselves without damaging the device. The assumption that the solution even necessarily involves creation of a 'master key' is false. Apple's encryption is device-specific and the encryption key is created from a hash which involves the user passcode as well as the hardware PIN. They could easily have come up with a solution that only applies to that device. And furthermore, the solution would obviously only apply to phones which are in the physical possession of the law. Apple was really clever, trying to cultivate their public image as "champions of the people", but have you considered that maybe they just don't want their encryption to appear weak? They got what they deserved anyways, because some lone hackers managed to crack it and show that it actually is weak after all

3:15 Only in the same way that I can, your device needs to have been compromised by said spy agency, or some incautious other person who left their access available to others, in order for this to happen. While government agencies are terrifying, and must be crippled, we don't need to give them any more fear power than they already have. Additionally, most webcams have a light hardwired in, and this light is forced to activate by the firmware, which anyone who has ever tried low level hardware modification can tell you, is very difficult to do, and completely impossible to do without physical access, so that really does weaken the "without you noticing bit. Again, I'm not saying these agencies aren't too powerful, quit the opposite in fact, I'm simply saying that by adding things they can't to to the list of things we think they can do, we give them more power than they already have, or deserve.

On the iPhone thing, at no point did anyone serious actually think Apple's involvement was necessary for that to be accomplished, the iPhone's security capabilities are rather impressive, but they are far from unbeatable. The full documentation is available here:
https://www.apple.com/business/docs/iOS_Security_Guide.pdf
Any one of you crazy enough to go read that and go through the trouble of understanding it will find what was already obvious, the only thing that truly needed to be brute forced on that phone was the 4-digit pin, all the other information needed to decrypt the data was available on the phone was there somewhere encoded in hardware. The trick was, under the basic operating system, information vital to reading any data was erased after ten unsuccessful attempts. But all this meant was that the operating system needed to be modified to allow more attempts, or better yet, the relevant encrypted information needed to be retrieved, and brute forced in a different environment altogether. Either of these processes would be resource intensive, but totally doable. I'm not totally sure what their motivation for asking Apple before doing this was, they may have wanted the publicity, either of Apple yielding to their demands (obviously didn't work), or taking advantage of the publicity from Apple's predictable refusal, to publicize just how "capable" they are, or maybe they wanted to simplify the process, either to avert cost, or because they where unaware of how relatively simple the process was, maybe they even wanted to take such a relatively simple case, unlock the dead terrorist's phone please, to establish a court precedent that they could use later. In the end, I can almost guarantee they hired someone to do it, because if they had the capabilities to do it internally, they would have kept quiet about it.

Just a bit of clarifications about the French thing: what you said in the video isn't completely wrong but it's not completely true either.

Our (I'm french, hence the pronoun) president put the country in what translates as "state of emergency". Basically, this was intended to close the borders in order to prevent the terrorists who might have still been out there to flee the country. It also meant that the police had more "rights" if you will to conduct searches in people's homes without necessarily having to justify their intentions to the judicial branch of the government (again, intended to give less time for terrorists in flight to do something).

The state of emergency also states that there can be no gathering of people, such as protests for instance. Whether or not the COP 21 protests were dispersed because of the state of emergency or because they didn't agree with the conference is another debate however.

So while what is reported in the video is true, the french government didn't take advantage of the situation to authorise more surveillance and less privacy. Unjustified house raids and protest dispersion were a side effect, an abuse of power as it were of the police and other law enforcing agencies, or at least, that's what the common thought is in France. And, let's be honest, if they hadn't declared the state of emergency, we probably would have been equally as upset about it all ... Because we're French. And there is nothing the French can't be pissed about.

Great video. Just a small critique:
It is a little bit sensationalist to include the possibility of eavesdropping from a "powered down" iPhone without some caveats. While yes, it is technically possible it is also extremely difficult to achieve with just a software stack exploit with the user inadvertently installing some sort of malware, etc (and flat out impossible without the user falling for something like that). The only real way such a capability (Snowden didn't give the details) could be realised would be to physically intercept devices (for instance via shipping - like has been revealed with motherboards and routers bound for "questionable" countries) and tampered with. So while technically a target of interest could have his iPhone turned into a "bug" - it isn't really a cause for concern for the average iPhone user which you sort of implied with the framing in this video.
